FYI, I have updated the "using OpenBMC" document "modify and configure" section to reference this text.  It reads:

The BMC hardware may have features with security related implications that should be taken into consideration when creating a firmware distribution because they increase the attack surface of the BMC.  These are identified in the OpenBMC functional specification and are specific to the hardware model, for example ASPEED AST2500 or Nuvoton W83795 series.  Example items include:
 - disable unneeded bridges between the BMC and host server such as PCIe-to-AHB, LPC-to-AHB, and UART-to-AHB.
 - disable debug or trace modes

I don't have a strong hardware background.  AHB refers to Advanced High-performance Bus (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Microcontroller_Bus_Architecture) that bridge the BMC to ??? the host processors?

> I don't have a strong hardware background.  AHB refers to Advanced High-performance Bus (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Microcontroller_Bus_Architecture) that bridge the BMC to ??? the host processors?

The ASPEED BMC SoCs have an ARM core, and the AHB is the high-speed internal bus connecting the ARM core to some "peripherals" in the SoC such as the network MAC, USB and SPI controllers. Other "peripherals" that hang off the AHB are devices that straddle the AHB and other buses - e.g. PCI-to-AHB and LPC-to-AHB. These bridges perform access translation between the two separate domains. Somewhat relevant is that the PCI and LPC buses are mastered (controlled) by the host (there's a bit of handwaving there on the LPC part).

So to answer your question, the AHB does not bridge the BMC to the host directly. Rather, one or more bridge devices that sit on the AHB allow accesses that cross domains between BMC and host buses.

Part of the picture here is the BMC's "physical address space". In the BMC's case, each of the peripherals exposed on the internal buses can be addressed by the ARM core's load and store instructions. Despite the hardware being physically arranged in a tree topology, this tree is flattened into a "physical" linear address space by the AHB controller (in the SoC). The PCI-to-AHB and LPC-to-AHB bridges translate commands from the relevant bus (PCI or LPC) into accesses on this linear, physical address space internal to the BMC.

Going with RFC2119 here, I think we should use RECOMMENDED. In the ideal world they should be requirements, but OpenPOWER systems need to judiciously violate some items in order to boot.

https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2119.txt

Here is how the Common Criteria model addresses this:

First establish the scope of what you working on, then identify security risks within that scope, and finally address those risks in different ways.

The document identifies the scope as the BMC and its firmware, and does not include the BMC's environment or data center.  That sounds right to me.

For items in scope, the security docs address risks in the form of requirements and recommendations.  A justification must be provided for an implementation that goes against the recommendations.

Items out of scope (such as the "non goals" below) form an important part of the overall security model and become "guidance" for downstream teams.  The downstream teams typically interpret this guidance as requirements and recommendations for items such as the operational environment, operator training, etc.

In this context, the "non-goals" are the same as Common Criteria "security assumptions" (which must be listed explicitly).
The main idea is to delineate what the OpenBMC project is doing and what must be provided somewhere else.  Examples:
 - OpenBMC is not doing anything to protect against bricking.  Yes this is a security concern (DoS attack).  This item explicitly mentions that fact.  Possible uses of this item are: raise the alarm for a implementation, or input into requirements for a BMC OEM.
 - OpenBMC is not protecting against physical attacks.  This is a legitimate security concern, and listing it as a non-goal is where we mention it.

What happens when XYZ corp needs brick protection, so they implement it, and then then contribute it to the project?  Do we now just remove it from the list of non-goals?  What did specifying that in the first place do for us?

Think of it this way: The non-goals are telling the downstream development teams the security relevant items that OpenBMC does not address, so they had better address it.  They have real options here: make a custom change for their particular situation, address the issue through environmental or procedural constraints, or live with the exposure.

In the happy chance that OpenBMC does address the issue in the future, we will remove this non-goal from the list.
